title: Mismatch-Robust Underwater Acoustic Localization Using A Differentiable Modular Forward Model
author: Dariush Kari (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Yongjie Zhuang (Stony Brook University), Andrew C. Singer (Stony Brook University), ...
relevance_why: The paper’s focus on robust localization in underwater acoustics using a differentiable modular forward model aligns with methodologies applicable to audio signal processing tasks that deal with environmental adaptation and localization.
background: Underwater acoustic localization methods can struggle with environmental mismatches, thus requiring adaptation techniques to ensure accurate source localization.
contribution: This paper introduces a gradient-based localization method that optimizes both the source location and the model parameters to enhance underwater acoustic localization performance amidst environmental mismatches.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods typically rely on fixed models that do not adapt to changes in the environmental conditions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by allowing simultaneous optimization over model parameters and inputs, which helps in adapting to new, unseen environments effectively.

key_innovation: The unique modular structure of the network allows for end-to-end training while respecting the physics-based characteristics of underwater sound propagation.
real_world_impact: The proposed method has the potential to significantly enhance underwater navigation and monitoring systems, improving operational capabilities in marine environments.
limitations: The performance under large environmental mismatches is not guaranteed, indicating that the robustness of adaptation could be restricted.

new_terms.gradient-based optimization: **Gradient-based optimization** refers to methods that utilize the gradient of a loss function to find the parameter values that minimize this function.
new_terms.maximum likelihood estimator: **Maximum likelihood estimator** is a statistical method used for estimating the parameters of a model that maximizes the likelihood of the observed data.
